elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of copper(I) or copper(II) salts with guanazole (3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole = Hdatrz) have yielded three novel 3D Cu-guanazolate complexes, that is, [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1), [Cu(datrz)] (2), and [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2] (3). Complex 1 presents the first example in Cu(I) halide complexes with its Cu(I) bromide units {Cu7Br6} n n+ adopting a 3D network, which is constructed from two unprecedented substructures: the edge-sharing eight-membered {Cu4Br4} n rings and the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4}n units. Guanazolate ligands in 1 adopt an unprecedented pentadentate bridging mode and some bromide ligands exhibit a rare umbrella-like μ 4 coordination geometry. The first binary Cu(I) guanazolate 2 exhibits a seldom reported two-fold interpenetrated lvt-a net, which can be partially controlled through the fixing effect of inter-ligand hydrogen bonds. Cu(II) complex 3 comprises a rarely encountered 12-connected tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBU, which is bridged by guanazolate ligands adopting a peculiar quadridentate coordination mode. This complex displays a non-interpenetrated pcu net, which is first constructed from multinuclear Cu(II) SBUs. Both 1 and 2 exhibit strong, broad, and unstructured emissions with long luminescence lifetimes, which may be assigned to the 3[MLCT] ES, and the 3[MC] or 3[MMLCT] ES could also be possible for 1. Complex 3 exhibits magnetic properties with four Cu(II) centers antiferromagnetically coupled in a tetranuclear array, which enables multiple and strong exchange interactions of J 1 = −95.1, J 2 = −152.7, and J 3 = −55.4 cm−1. All compounds of this study display a medium to high thermal stability, and complex 1 shows the highest one with its structure framework unchanged up to 540 °C. Some significant structure−function correlations are discussed in this study as well.

elements.content: Three novel Cu(I)− or Cu(II)−guanazolate complexes 1−3 have been prepared hydrothermally. Unprecedented structural characteristics and guanzolate coordination mode of 1, interesting network topologies of 2 and 3, photoluminescence properties of 1 and 2, magnetic properties of 3, and their thermal stability have been systematically investigated, and some significant function-structure correlations are discussed as well.

elements.content: The significant contemporary interest in design and synthesis of coordination complexes reflects their widespread applications in areas as diverse as catalysis, gas storage, sorption, magnetics, optics, and microelectronics. Although a large number of complexes with intriguing structures and physical properties have been reported, rational establishing structure−function correlations within these materials still remains a challenge in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering. To this end, the skillful selection of appropriate organic ligands and metal ions is pivotal for preparing novel complexes with desired properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The significant contemporary interest in design and synthesis of coordination complexes reflects their widespread applications in areas as diverse as catalysis, gas storage, sorption, magnetics, optics, and microelectronics. Although a large number of complexes with intriguing structures and physical properties have been reported, rational establishing structure-function correlations within these materials still remains a challenge in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering. To this end, the skillful selection of appropriate organic ligands and metal ions is pivotal for preparing novel complexes with desired properties.

elements.content: Guanazole ligand (3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole = Hdatrz) has been demonstrated by our earlier study to be able to manifest a remarkable coordination versatility in a Cd(II)−guanazole hybrid family with as much as five bridging modes varying from bidentate to quadridentate, through the control of inorganic or organic anions. As an extension of the previous work, copper ions are incorporated instead of cadmium ions into the metal−guanazole system in this study, since Cu(I) and Cu(II) complexes have been of great interest for their large structural variation, novel topologies, as well as attractive physical properties. For example, photoluminescence properties of Cu(I) complexes are characterized by large quantum yields, long-lived emissions, and rich variety of luminactive excited states. And Cu(II) complexes are endowed with tunable magnetic properties from a wide variety of structural formats, including dinuclear, linear trinuclear, triangular trinuclear, one-dimensional (1D) chain, two-dimensional (2D) network structure, and so forth. Although many Cu−triazolate complexes have been documented, only four Cu−guanazolate structures have been reported to date, and three of them are zero-dimensional (discrete). Due to this scarcity, it is sorely needed to systematically investigate the rich structure chemistry and structure−function correlations in Cu(I)− and Cu(II)−guanazolate complexes, as well as the coordination versatility of the guanazole ligand itself.

elements.content: On the other hand, network topology is authenticated to be a powerful tool in analyzing and designing new coordination complexes. Simple topologies with high-symmetry built from simple ligands and fewer components (e.g. binary complexes) are worth special attention due to their accessible structural prediction. Accordingly, the guanazole ligand can be a good candidate to construct simple and important 3- or 4-connected nets not only for its simplicity but also for its predictable bridging modes (tridentate or quadridentate). Three- or four-coordinate copper centers can also serve as connected nodes. Therefore, well-defined network topologies may be successfully assembled from Cu−guanazolate complexes in a straightforward way. To the best of our knowledge, systematical investigation of network topologies of Cu−guanazolate complexes is seldom known.

elements.content: Herein, we present a comprehensive investigation of three novel Cu(I)− or Cu(II)−guanazolate complexes, [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1), [Cu(datrz)] (2), and [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2] (3). The coordination versatility of the guanazole ligand in these complexes manifests three bridging modes (Scheme , type A−C), and the pentadentate one is first reported (type C). Moreover, interesting network topologies of 2 and 3, photoluminescence properties of 1 and 2, magnetic properties of 3, and some significant function−structure correlations have also been studied, as well as other physical properties like thermal stability, XRD, etc.

The coordination versatility of the guanazole ligand in these complexes manifests three bridging modes (Scheme , type A-C), and the pentadentate one is first reported (type C). Moreover, interesting network topologies of 2 and 3, photoluminescence properties of 1 and 2, magnetic properties of 3, and some significant function-structure correlations have also been studied, as well as other physical properties like thermal stability, XRD, etc.

Commercially available reagents were used as received without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The IR spectroscopy was recorded on a PECO (U.S.A.) SpectrumOne spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. The elemental analyses were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer. The thermal decomposition behavior of 1 was analyzed by TGA-MS using the NETSCH STA-449C thermoanalyzer coupled with a NETSCH QMS403C massspectrometer. The fluorescence spectra were measured on polycrystalline or powder samples at room temperature using an Edinburgh FLS920 TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements for powder samples of 3 were carried out with a Quantum Design PPMS model 6000 magnetometer in the 1.8−300 K range. The applied magnetic field was 5 kG, and the data were corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal’s constants and the temperature-independent paramagnetism estimated at 60 × 10−6 emu mol−1 per Cu(II) ion. The phase purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by powder XRD using a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). A step size of 0.05° and counting time of 1.2 s /step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.00−55.00°. The observed and simulated powder XRD patterns of all compounds are displayed in Figure S1 ().

elements.content: A mixture of CuBr (0.14g, 1.00 mmol), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.05g, 0.25 mmol), and Hdatrz (0.05g, 0.5 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner; 2 mL of ethanol and 8 mL of water were then added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 5 min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 160 °C. The temperature was held for 3 days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 0.5 °C min−1 to form pale-yellow prism crystals of 1. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C4H8Br6Cu8N10: C, 4.06; H, 0.68; N, 11.83; Br, 40.49. Found: C, 4.04; H, 0.69; N, 11.86; Br, 40.45%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm−1) for complex 1: 3325 (s), 1682 (m), 1650 (s), 1632 (s), 1600 (m), 1563 (m), 1516 (m), 1477 (m), 1375 (m) 1097 (w), 764 (w).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1−3 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed on a Siemens Smart CCD Diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ Mo Kα = 0.71073 Å) at T = 294.15 K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were fixed at their ideal positions. And the water hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data and refinement of 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1 ().

All compounds of this study were synthesized in good yields by exploiting the hydrothermal reactions of guanazole with the appropriate Cu(II) or Cu(I) salts. Through varying the reaction conditions, we noted that the hydrothermal chemistry of Cu-guanzolate complexes is remarkably sensitive to three factors: pH value, copper source, and stoichiometry. In our experiments, complex 1 could be generally prepared under acid pH conditions, whereas the optimal pH range for providing good yields and well-crystalline products is 3.0-4.5 (using 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid). When the pH value was adjusted above 8.5 (using 25% aqueous ammonia), strikingly, only brown prism crystals of 2 were obtained regardless of what kind of copper salt was added (CuCl2•2H2O, CuSO4•5H2O, CuBr2, CuCl, CuBr, etc., have been investigated). In other words, in an alkaline hydrothermal environment, inorganic anions (Cl−, Br−, SO4 2−, etc.) of copper salts can not be incorporated into the final products, and copper cations are only charge-balanced by guanazolate ligands. By the way, nitrogenous ligands have been noted to be reducing under hydrothermal conditions, and consequently the formation of Cu(I) complexes from Cu(II) materials is not uncommon. When sulfate ions are incorporated instead of halogen ions into the Cu−guanazolate system, blue sheet crystals of 3 were obtained. Scheme shows the hydrothermal syntheses of these compounds.

Synthesis and Infrared Spectroscopy

All compounds of this study were synthesized in good yields by exploiting the hydrothermal reactions of guanazole with the appropriate Cu(II) or Cu(I) salts. Through varying the reaction conditions, we noted that the hydrothermal chemistry of Cu-guanzolate complexes is remarkably sensitive to three factors: pH value, copper source, and stoichiometry. In our experiments, complex 1 could be generally prepared under acid pH conditions, whereas the optimal pH range for providing good yields and well-crystalline products is 3.0-4.5 (using 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid). When the pH value was adjusted above 8.5 (using 25% aqueous ammonia), strikingly, only brown prism crystals of 2 were obtained regardless of what kind of copper salt was added (CuCl2⋅2H2O, CuSO4⋅5H2O, CuBr2, CuCl, CuBr, etc., have been investigated). In other words, in an alkaline hydrothermal environment, inorganic anions (Cl-, Br-, SO4 2-, etc.) of copper salts can not be incorporated into the final products, and copper cations are only charge-balanced by guanazolate ligands. By the way, nitrogenous ligands have been noted to be reducing under hydrothermal conditions, and consequently the formation of Cu(I) complexes from Cu(II) materials is not uncommon. When sulfate ions are incorporated instead of halogen ions into the Cu-guanazolate system, blue sheet crystals of 3 were obtained. Scheme  shows the hydrothermal syntheses of these compounds.

elements.content: Copper(I) halide complexes with nitrogen bases have long been of interest because of the diversity of structure types formed. In the study by Graham et al., a number of basic structural types for Cu(I) halide polymers have been elucidated and elaborated upon. Two common types for Cu(I) halide complexes are so-called the “chain” and the “stair step”. The “chain” polymer has linear 1D chains of −(CuX)− repeat units. These chains can form 2D sheets when pendant ligands bridge copper atoms on adjacent chains. Alternatively, the “stair step” polymer has square −(Cu2X2)− units that form the step of a stair. In addition, polymers with the tetranuclear cubane−(Cu4X4)− unit are documented extensively as well. It should be pointed out that most of these inorganic Cu(I) halide units have low structural dimensionality (from 0D to 2D), and serve as discrete charge-balancing components or low-dimensional substructures. To the best of our knowledge, there is no previous report about the Cu(I) halide complex with its inorganic Cu(I) halide units adopting the 3D framework structure. In this study, however, [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1) (Figure a) presents the first example comprising 3D Cu(I) bromide framework, that is, {Cu7Br6} n n+, as shown in Figure b. This cationic framework is constructed from two types of substructural units: one is the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4} n units linked through μ 4-Br (Br4) atoms; the other is the edge-sharing eight-membered {Cu4Br4} n rings. To our knowledge, both of them are first reported in copper(I) halide complexes. These two substructural units are propagating along the b-axis, besides, the paddle-wheel-like units also extend along the c-axis through the linkage of Br4 atoms, thus affording a 3D network with its cavities occupied by anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n n- units (Figure b and c). It is noteworthy that although these two kinds of units are stoichiometrically identical, that is, {Cu4Br4} n , their skeleton structure are quite different. Hence, two distinct Cu(I) bromide structure types are simultaneously embedded in a single complex, which is first encountered as well.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Studies of [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1)

Copper(I) halide complexes with nitrogen bases have long been of interest because of the diversity of structure types formed. In the study by Graham et al., a number of basic structural types for Cu(I) halide polymers have been elucidated and elaborated upon. Two common types for Cu(I) halide complexes are so-called the "chain" and the "stair step". The "chain" polymer has linear 1D chains of -(CuX)- repeat units. These chains can form 2D sheets when pendant ligands bridge copper atoms on adjacent chains. Alternatively, the "stair step" polymer has square -(Cu2X2)- units that form the step of a stair. In addition, polymers with the tetranuclear cubane-(Cu4X4)- unit are documented extensively as well. It should be pointed out that most of these inorganic Cu(I) halide units have low structural dimensionality (from 0D to 2D), and serve as discrete charge-balancing components or low-dimensional substructures. To the best of our knowledge, there is no previous report about the Cu(I) halide complex with its inorganic Cu(I) halide units adopting the 3D framework structure. In this study, however, [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1) (Figure a) presents the first example comprising 3D Cu(I) bromide framework, that is, {Cu7Br6} n   n+, as shown in Figure b. This cationic framework is constructed from two types of substructural units: one is the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4} n  units linked through μ 4-Br (Br4) atoms; the other is the edge-sharing eight-membered {Cu4Br4} n  rings. To our knowledge, both of them are first reported in copper(I) halide complexes. These two substructural units are propagating along the b-axis, besides, the paddle-wheel-like units also extend along the c-axis through the linkage of Br4 atoms, thus affording a 3D network with its cavities occupied by anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n   n- units (Figure b and c). It is noteworthy that although these two kinds of units are stoichiometrically identical, that is, {Cu4Br4} n , their skeleton structure are quite different. Hence, two distinct Cu(I) bromide structure types are simultaneously embedded in a single complex, which is first encountered as well.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a and b, Cu(I) coordination sites in the cationic framework {Cu7Br6} n n+ all exhibit a four-coordinate distorted tetrahedral geometry, whereas it can be classified into two categories: the first (Cu2 and Cu4) is defined by two amino nitrogen donors and two bromide ligands; the second (Cu3 and Cu5) is defined by a guanazolate N1/N2 (for Cu3) or N4 (for Cu5) nitrogen donor and three bromide ligands. Particularly, anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n n- units all exhibit two-coordinate {CuN2} sites (for Cu1), which are distinct from other copper sites of 1. The low coordination numbers of Cu1 sites may be partially attributed to that {Cu(datrz)2} n n- units are confined in the cavities of the {Cu7Br6} n n+ network, which can effectively block some coordination sites of Cu1 centers. Upon this, a promising approach to synthesize complexes with low coordinated Cu(I) centers could be suggested through confining Cu(I)-organic motifs into a rigid 3D inorganic porous network. From this work, we note that four-coordinate {CuN2Br2}, {CuNBr3} sites and two-coordinate {CuN2} sites are all incorporated in a complex, which is unprecedented and enriches the coordination chemistry of Cu(I) halide complexes. As highlighted as red dotted lines in Figure a and b, three short Cu···Cu interactions occur within the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4} n units (2.785 Å for Cu2···Cu6, 2.990 Å for Cu5···Cu6 and Cu6···Cu5#8), and these interactions may profoundly influence the luminescence properties of 1.

elements.content: In this complex, Br− anions are involved in two kinds of coordination geometry. Br1, Br3, and Br5 all form a μ 3 bridge, showing a distorted trigonal pyramidal geometry but with the Br5 atom lying only 0.48 Å out of the plane of the copper atoms. Interestingly, Br2 and Br4 exhibit a very rare umbrella-like μ 4 bridging geometry (Figure b), which can be visualized as the μ 3 geometry of Br2 or Br4 adding a fourth Cu ion below the base of the three Cu atoms, and only two similar examples have been reported.

elements.content: Finally, of special interest is the coordination mode of the guanazole ligand in 1. We have recently explored the coordination diversity of this ligand in a Cd(II)−guanazole system, obtaining the novel quadridentate N1, N2, N4, amino N-bridging mode with four of five nitrogen atoms bonding to Cd sites (Scheme , type B). Whereas in complex 1 of this study, all five nitrogen atoms of this ligand participate in the coordination, affording an unprecedented pentadentate N1, N2, N4, diamino N-bridging mode (Scheme , type C), as shown in Figure a and c. This μ 5-guanazolate ligand not only bridges five distinct Cu(I) sites (Cu1−Cu5) but also serves as the deprotonated charge-balancing component, which can significantly fix and stabilize the cationic {Cu7Br6} n n+ network, forming a much rigid and stable 3D framework of 1 (Figure c).

elements.content: To investigate other Cu(I) halide complexes with the guanazole as ligand, CuCl and CuCl2•2H2O were used instead of CuBr. Despite repeated attempts, no conditions could be found to provide Cu/datrz/Cl− phase. However, in this exploring we discovered that the new complex [Cu(datrz)] (2) could be prepared exclusively either from Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in an alkaline hydrothermal environment. As shown in Figure a, [Cu(datrz)] (2) is a binary metal guanazolate complex, within which each ligand adopts a tridentate N1, N2, N4-bridging mode (Scheme , type A) and each Cu(I) site exhibits a trigonal-planar geometry, producing a 3D network. It is known that from the topological point of view, binary metal-organic complexes with trigonal-planar coordinated metal centers and tridentate ligands should be the most viable candidates to construct simple and high-symmetrical 3-connected networks in a predictable way. However, only very few of this kind of binary complexes has been synthesized, and no X-ray structure of binary metal-guanazolate has been reported to date. As illustrated in Figure b, the 3D 3-connected topological net for 2 exhibits a two-fold interpenetrated lvt-a net with Schläfli (short) symbol 4.8.10 and vertex symbol 4.8.163 (The 10-gons in the Schlafli symbol are circuits containing shortcuts while the 16-gons are the smallest fundamental rings.). The uninodal lvt-a net is rarely appearing in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and only two examples have been reported to our knowledge.

elements.content: We note that Chen et al have proposed a construction strategy for some important 3- or 4-connected topologies through controlling the dihedral angle between adjacent planar secondary building units (SBUs). When the dihedral angle is acute, the lvt-a net may be formed (for complex 2, the dihedral angle is 55.5°). Although the factors that influence the dihedral angle are commonly ascribed to the steric hindrance of the substituents of organic ligands, more crucial determinants have been found in complex 2 of this study. As shown in Figure c, there are inter-ligand hydrogen bonding interactions between adjacent amino groups (N4−H4a···N4: 3.256(2) Å; N4−H4B···N3: 3.243(3) Å). These hydrogen bonds can effectively fix the dihedral angle through definite bond lengths and angles. Therefore, this study suggests a promising way to construct important 3- or 4-connected topologies by using appropriate organic ligands with their substituents (e.g., −NH2, −SH, −Cl, etc.) being able to form suitable hydrogen bonding interactions which can effectively control the dihedral angle between adjacent planar SBUs. And complex 2, with its prominent facile synthetic conditions, shows the first case.

elements.content: When sulfate ions are incorporated instead of halogen ions into the Cu−guanazolate system, a tetranuclear Cu(II) complex [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2] (3) is obtained (Figure a). This complex exhibits two distinct Cu(II) geometries: Cu1 is in a square planar configuration defined by a μ 3-hydroxy ligand, an oxygen donor from a μ 2-sulfate group, a N1 (N2) nitrogen site and an amino nitrogen site (respectively from two guanazolate ligands); Cu2 exhibits a five-coordinate square pyramidal geometry (the parameter τ = 0.018), with the basal plane occupied by two μ 3-hydroxy ligands, a guanazolate N4 nitrogen donor and a guanazolate N1 (N2) nitrogen donor, and the apical position occupied by a sulfate oxygen site. In this complex, four- and five-coordinate Cu(II) centers construct a 12-connected tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBU (Figure a). This high connected SBU is rarely encountered in the coordination chemistry, and only 7 examples have been reported to date. In these examples, distinct Cu(II) sites of this SBU are unanimously linked by two kinds of ligands; however, in complex 3, only guanazolate ligands are involved in the linkage. This interesting observation may be associated with the peculiar coordination mode of the guanazolate ligand in 3, namely, the quadridentate N1, N2, N4, amino N-bridging mode (Scheme , type B). This coordination mode was only found in Cd(II) complexes previously, and complex 3 presents the first example of embedding it in Cu(II) complexes.

In this complex, four- and five-coordinate Cu(II) centers construct a 12-connected tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBU (Figure a). This high connected SBU is rarely encountered in the coordination chemistry, and only 7 examples have been reported to date. In these examples, distinct Cu(II) sites of this SBU are unanimously linked by two kinds of ligands; however, in complex 3, only guanazolate ligands are involved in the linkage. This interesting observation may be associated with the peculiar coordination mode of the guanazolate ligand in 3, namely, the quadridentate N1, N2, N4, amino N-bridging mode (Scheme , type B). elements.content: As shown in Figure b, tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBUs are bridged by μ 2-sulfate groups forming a 1D chain substructure, which can be described as 4-membered Cu−O rings plus 12-membered Cu−O−S rings propagating along the a-axis. Parallel 1D chains are linked each other through quadridentate guanazolate ligands, affording a complex 3D network as illustrated in Figure c. For this network, if we consider the guanazolate ligands as 4-connected nodes, μ 3-hydroxy as 3-connected nodes, Cu(II) atoms respectively as 4-connected nodes and 5-connected nodes, a 4-nodal net with new topology can be presented with Schläfli symbol (43)(42.63.8)(42.84)(43.64.83) (Figure S2, ). This topology is quite complicated and can be further simplified to a 6-connected uninodal 412.63-pcu (primitive cubic packing) net (or α-polonium net) by considering tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBUs as 6-connected nodes, the guanazolate ligands and sulfate groups as linkers, as shown in Figure a and b. This simplification is based on that each 12-connected SBU is bridging to six adjacent counterparts in positions the same as for Na+ and Cl− in NaCl (Figure a). It is noteworthy that this pcu net is not interpenetrated, which is less frequently encountered in meta-organic frameworks. To our knowledge, most of reported pcu nets are built from Zn(II) or Cd(II) SBUs, and no report has been found in the literature so far about the non-interpenetrated pcu net constructed from multinuclear Cu(II) SBUs. By the way, metal-organic complexes that are based on pcu nets have been demonstrated to exhibit remarkable physical properties, like porous hydrogen storage capabilities reported by Yaghi et al., and magnetic properties of the Prussian blue family. Hence, the assembly of compounds with pcu topology is significant in solid-state coordination chemistry.

elements.content: The thermal stability and thermolysis behavior of 1 were specially analyzed by means of TGA-QMS, that is, a measurement of TG instruments on-line coupled with a quadrupole mass spectrometer, under 10 mL min−1 flowing nitrogen, at a rate of 10 °C min−1 from 40 to 900 °C. Other compounds were studied by TG/DTA under an air atmosphere with a flowing rate of 20 mL min−1 from 40 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

The thermal stability and thermolysis behavior of 1 were specially analyzed by means of TGA-QMS, that is, a measurement of TG instruments on-line coupled with a quadrupole mass spectrometer, under 10 mL min-1 flowing nitrogen, at a rate of 10 °C min-1 from 40 to 900 °C. Other compounds were studied by TG/DTA under an air atmosphere with a flowing rate of 20 mL min-1 from 40 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: The TG curve of 1 (Figure a) is almost unchanged up to 320 °C, which suggests that its framework is robust and thermally stable. Then a steady, moderate to steep weight loss up to 720 °C is observed without any obvious well-defined plateau, and that is associated with the decomposition of organic ligands and the sublimation of CuBr (exptl, 89.19%; calcd, 89.27%) to leave a residue of Cu. TGA-QMS analysis reveal that the loss of NH2 and CN groups dominates the initial decomposition phase (320 to 500 °C) of guanazole ligands, authenticated by detectable ion currents of NH2 + (m/z = 16) and CN+ (m/z = 26), as shown in Figure a and b. Above 540 °C, detectable ion currents (m/z = 16, NH2 +; m/z = 26, 52 for CN+; m/z = 38 for C2N+) are associated with the complete combustion of organic ligands, leading to the structure collapse. The thermodiffraction profile for 1 (Figure ) is strikingly unchanged between 50 and 540 °C, manifesting that its structural integrity can be retained far beyond the initial decomposition temperature and partial loss of organic components does not result in structure collapse. This observation of 1 is seldom reported in copper-triazolate (or substituted triazolate) complexes, and may be mainly attributed to its rigid and stable 3D inorganic network of {Cu7Br6} n which is densely linked by pentadentate guanazolate ligands as discussed before. It is noteworthy that complex 1 displays the highest thermal stability among all compounds of this study, and it is also much higher than other reported Cu−triazolate structures. The remarkably high thermal stability of 1 is related with its peculiar molecular structure, and that also suggests a straightforward way to tune structure-related thermal stabilities of metal-organic complexes.

elements.content: The TG curves of 2 and 3 (Figures S3 and S4, ) are likewise unchanged up to 280 °C, showing a moderate high thermal stability of these materials. For 2, a weight loss from 280 to 450 °C is consistent with the decomposition of organic ligands (exptl, 50.12%; calcd, 50.79%). Differently, complex 3 manifests a very sharp loss of hydroxy groups and all organic components in the temperature range of 280-365 °C (exptl, 33.24%; calcd, 34.03%). After a plateau of stability between 365 and 625 °C, the second weight loss process is observed, corresponding to the combustion of sulfate groups (exptl, 18.41%; calcd, 18.94%).

elements.content: In this work, photoluminescence properties of 1 and 2 have been explored at room temperature in the solid state, since they are virtually insoluble in common solvents such as water, ethanol, acetone, chloroform, benzene, etc. Both 1 and 2 exhibit bright phosphorescence at room temperature, and for the sake of easier discussion, we FIRST introduce photoluminescence properties for 2, then for 1.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

In this work, photoluminescence properties of 1 and 2 have been explored at room temperature in the solid state, since they are virtually insoluble in common solvents such as water, ethanol, acetone, chloroform, benzene, etc. Both 1 and 2 exhibit bright phosphorescence at room temperature, and for the sake of easier discussion, we FIRST introduce photoluminescence properties for 2, then for 1.

elements.content: Compound 2 has a strong emission band at λ max em = 516 nm (Figure ) with a lifetime of 18.73 μs (Figure S5, ). It is noted that this compound has a relatively long Cu···Cu distance (3.48 Å), which is longer than the sum of van der Waals radii for copper (2.8 Å), so direct metal···metal interactions in the ground state are improbable. Otherwise, we have previously investigated that the free guanazole ligand could display a broad emission with the maximum at 435nm in H2O solution, whereas in the solid state so weak to be neglectable. Therefore the emission of 2 may be assigned as originating from 3[MLCT] excited state (ES), and this assignment is also authenticated by its broad and unstructured emission spectrum, as well as its long luminescence lifetime on the microsecond timescale. Compared with reported Cu(I)−triazolates, the maximum emission wavelength of 2 is red-shifted by about 20−40 nm and its luminescence lifetime is longer. This red-shift may be partially attributed to that in the guanazole ligand, electron-donating amino groups can significantly increase the conjugation degree of the parent five-membered aromatic heteroring. In addition, it should be noted that the electron density on the nitrogen atom is reduced on excitation, so that the ability to form hydrogen bonds is lower in the excited state. The ground state is thus more stabilized by hydrogen bonding than the excited state. This also results in a red-shift of the emission spectrum of 2 compared to Cu(I)−triazolate complexes without hydrogen bonds. As for the longer lifetime of 2, that may be associated with its two-fold interpenetrated 3-connected network which is further fixed by hydrogen bonds, thus affording much weaker vibrations. Therefore, hydrogen bonding interaction in 2 not only plays a important role in the construction of important 3-connected lvt-a topology, but also exerts a crucial influence on photoluminescence properties of 2.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 has a strong emission band at λ max em = 516 nm (Figure ) with a lifetime of 18.73 μs (Figure S5, ). It is noted that this compound has a relatively long Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance (3.48 Å), which is longer than the sum of van der Waals radii for copper (2.8 Å), so direct metal⋅⋅⋅metal interactions in the ground state are improbable. Otherwise, we have previously investigated that the free guanazole ligand could display a broad emission with the maximum at 435nm in H2O solution, whereas in the solid state so weak to be neglectable. Therefore the emission of 2 may be assigned as originating from 3[MLCT] excited state (ES), and this assignment is also authenticated by its broad and unstructured emission spectrum, as well as its long luminescence lifetime on the microsecond timescale. elements.content: As for compound 1, it exhibits a broad blue to red emission band at λ max em = 548 nm with excitation at 330 nm (Figure ), and its luminescence lifetime (τ) is fitted to two components by a biexponential decay curve, i.e. τ 1 = 0.1657 μs, 58%; τ 2 = 0.6321 μs, 42% (Figure S6, ). This emission may be assigned to 3[MLCT] ES for its broad and structureless emission spectrum, as well as its lifetime on the microsecond timescale. Some of observed Cu···Cu distances (2.785 Å for Cu2···Cu6) in the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4}n units are shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii for copper (2.8 Å), indicative of the presence of weak metal···metal interactions. Hence, the metal-centered 3[MC] or metal−metal bond to ligand charge transfer 3[MMLCT] ES should be possible for this compound as well. Although the plotted spectra are normalized, we note that the emission of 1 is much brighter (5×) than that of 2, and compound 1 exhibits a red shift of 30nm for its emission band in contrast to 2, both of which may be presumably ascribed to the contribution of the aforementioned MMLCT (dσ* → pσ/π * ) transition.

elements.content: The luminescence decay of 1 is biexponential, which indicates two different chromophore environments in the polymer matrix. Therefore, we may tentatively consider one component with longer lifetime (τ 2 = 0.6321 μs) coming from the guanazolate ligands bridged {Cu7Br6} n n+ network for its rigid connection affording weaker vibrations. The other component (τ 1 = 0.1657 μs) may be associated with anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n n- units containing two-coordinate {CuN2} sites. It’s interesting that this study provides an accessible method to incorporate different chromophores into a luminescence polymer matrix through rationally embedding different SBUs in a framework structure, which also offers a practicable strategy to tune photoluminescence properties of metal-organic complexes.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data for polycrystalline sample of 3 are displayed in the form of a χ m T and χ m vs T plot, where χ m is the molar magnetic susceptibility as calculated with correcting for the diamagnetic contribution. The room-temperature value of χ m T for 3 is 0.54 cm3 K mol−1 (Figure ), which is significantly smaller than the expected value for four uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g = 2.0 (4χ m,Cu T = 1.5 cm3 K mol−1 and S = 1/2). Upon cooling, the χ m T value decreases continuously from room temperature until it vanishes near 2.5 K. The value of χ m is 0.0017 cm3 mol−1 at room temperature, and it increases smoothly to a maximum of 0.0046 cm3 mol−1 at 27 K and finally decreases to 0.0039 cm3 mol−1 at 2K.

Magnetic Properties of 3

Magnetic susceptibility data for polycrystalline sample of 3 are displayed in the form of a χ m T and χ m vs T plot, where χ m is the molar magnetic susceptibility as calculated with correcting for the diamagnetic contribution. The room-temperature value of χ m T for 3 is 0.54 cm3 K mol-1 (Figure ), which is significantly smaller than the expected value for four uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g = 2.0 (4χ m,Cu T = 1.5 cm3 K mol-1 and S = 1/2). Upon cooling, the χ m T value decreases continuously from room temperature until it vanishes near 2.5 K. The value of χ m is 0.0017 cm3 mol-1 at room temperature, and it increases smoothly to a maximum of 0.0046 cm3 mol-1 at 27 K and finally decreases to 0.0039 cm3 mol-1 at 2K.

elements.content: This magnetic behavior is characteristic of an antiferromagnetic interaction between spin magnetic moments of Cu(II) centers and the ground state is S = 0. As illustrated in Figure , four exchange constants J 1−J 4 are used to describe each possible pairwise exchange interaction between four Cu(II) centers of 3. Hence, the spin Hamiltonian taking the form of eq can be applied to interpret the magnetic interactions of this tetranuclear Cu(II) complex. An expression for the molar magnetic susceptibility can be derived from the van Vleck equation through solving the resulting energy matrix. Because of the rather long distance (6.040 Å) between Cu1 and Cu1#2, the value of J 4 should be negligible and fixed to 0 during fitting the magnetic data. It should be noted that a correction ρ is introduced to consider the percentage of paramagnetic impurity. The best-fit parameters obtained were: J 1 = −95.1, J 2 = −152.7, J 3 = −55.4 cm−1, g = 1.91, and ρ = 0.29% with the agreement factor R = 3.1 × 10−5 (R = Σ|(χ m T)exp − (χ m T)cal|2/Σ(χ m T)exp 2). elements.content: Form the molecular structure point of view, it has been concluded that the unpaired electron on each square pyramidal Cu(II) center is in a d(x - y 2) type magnetic orbital, which is located in the basal plane of the Cu(II) square pyramid. Differently, the magnetic exchange through the apical pathway can be expected to have little relevance since the unpaired electron density along the d(z ) orbital is quite low in the square pyramidal coordination around Cu(II) centers. In compound 3, double μ 3-hydroxide superexchange pathways (Cu2−O1−Cu2#2, Cu2−O1#2-Cu2#2) correspond to the basal positions, producing strong antiferromagnetic coupling with J 2 = −152.7 cm−1. On the other hand, short Cu2···Cu2#2 distance (2.985(2) Å) can afford an increase in the overlap between the orbitals on the Cu(II) centers and the bridges, which is also able to increase the antiferromagnetic coupling J 2. This short Cu···Cu distance may be associated with that quadridentate guanazolate ligands could contract the tetranuclear Cu(II) core through multiple and short Cu−N bonds.

On the other hand, short Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2#2 distance (2.985(2) Å) can afford an increase in the overlap between the orbitals on the Cu(II) centers and the bridges, which is also able to increase the antiferromagnetic coupling J 2. This short Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance may be associated with that quadridentate guanazolate ligands could contract the tetranuclear Cu(II) core through multiple and short Cu-N bonds.

elements.content: We note that most of reported tetranuclear Cu(II) complexes similar to 3 place their double μ 3-hydroxide exchange pathways along the d(z 2) orbital with long Cu···Cu distances, producing poor overlap between the magnetic orbitals of Cu(II) centers. Contrarily, complex 3 manifests the strong antiferromagnetic coupling both coming from double μ 3-hydroxide pathways and Cu···Cu interaction, and this is rarely reported to our knowledge.

elements.content: In addition, μ-guanazolate and single μ 3-hydroxide superexchange pathways also give a significant contribution to antiferromagnetic character of 3. For J 1 = -95.1cm−1, this coupling can be attributed to both the single μ 3-hydroxide pathway in the basal plane (Cu1−O1−Cu2) and the μ-guanazolate pathway (Cu1−N2−N3-Cu2). And the latter is considered to make less contribution than the former because Cu−N−N angles of 3 (116.37°, 116.75°) are smaller than the most optimized bridging angle of 135°, which would lead to the largest possible coupling of triazole-bridged Cu(II) complexes suggested by Haasnoot et al. The antiferromagnetic coupling J 3 is only associated with the single μ 3-hydroxide pathway (Cu2−O1−Cu1#2), affording a comparatively weak exchange interaction (J 3 = −55.4 cm−1).

elements.content: It is noteworthy that, although compound 3 has a small χ m T value, some significant magneto-structural correlations can be possibly established from this study. First, μ 3-O or μ 3-OH bridged tetranuclear metal complexes can afford multiple and strong exchange interactions when these bridge exchange pathways correspond to the high spin density orbitals of the coordination sphere around metal centers. Second, quadridentate guanazolate ligands not only can provide additional μ-guanazolate (metal−N−N−metal) exchange pathways, but also can contract the metal cluster through rich and short Cu−N bonds affording a reduction in the metal···metal distance. This reduction will increase both antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic interaction of complexes, and the latter character is more desirable. Therefore, more remarkable magnetic properties would be obtained if Cu(II) ions of 3 were changed into Fe(II), Mn(II) or rare earth ions. For example, a tetranuclear manganese complex with its metal core structure similar to 3 has been reported to be to able to function as a single molecule magnet (SMM) with a S = 9 ground state. Furthermore, compound 3 is based on a non-interpenetrated pcu net, from which Prussian blue like magnetic materials can be constructed. So if tetranuclear {M4(μ 3-OH)2} SBUs were linked through short bridges (e.g. using μ-O instead of μ-SO4 in 3), more attractive magnetic properties would be probably accomplished. On the basis of this work, further investigations are under way in our laboratory.

elements.content: In summary, we have investigated three novel 3D Cu-guanazolate complexes (1−3) synthesized hydrothermally through the appropriate control of reaction conditions, each with distinct nuclearity and metal-organic framework. Complex [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1) presents the first example in Cu(I) halide complexes with its Cu(I) bromide units {Cu7Br6} n n+ adopting a 3D framework structure, which is constructed from two unprecedented substructural units: the edge-sharing eight-membered {Cu4Br4} n rings and the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4} n units within which short Cu···Cu interactions occur to influence the luminescence properties of 1. Anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n n- units are confined in the cavities of the 3D {Cu7Br6} n n+ network to show low coordinated {CuN2} sites. Guanazolate ligands in 1 adopt an unprecedented pentadentate N1, N2, N4, diamino N-bridging mode (Scheme , type C) and some bromide ligands exhibit a very rare umbrella-like μ 4 bridging geometry. The first binary metal guanazolate 2 can be prepared exclusively either from Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in an alkaline hydrothermal environment, providing a facile synthetic condition. The 3D 3-connected topological net for 2 exhibits a seldom reported two-fold interpenetrated lvt-a net, which can be partially controlled through the fixing effect of inter-ligand hydrogen bonds. Cu(II) complex 3 comprises a rarely encountered 12-connected tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBU, which is bridged by guanazolate ligands adopting a peculiar quadridentate coordination mode (Scheme , type B). This complex forms a new topology of 4-nodal net (43)(42.63.8)(42.84)(43.64.83), and that can be simplified to a non-interpenetrated pcu net, which is first constructed from multinuclear Cu(II) SBUs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have investigated three novel 3D Cu-guanazolate complexes (1-3) synthesized hydrothermally through the appropriate control of reaction conditions, each with distinct nuclearity and metal-organic framework. Complex [Cu7Br6][Cu(datrz)2] (1) presents the first example in Cu(I) halide complexes with its Cu(I) bromide units {Cu7Br6} n   n+ adopting a 3D framework structure, which is constructed from two unprecedented substructural units: the edge-sharing eight-membered {Cu4Br4} n  rings and the three-bladed paddle-wheel-like {Cu4Br4} n  units within which short Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions occur to influence the luminescence properties of 1. Anionic {Cu(datrz)2} n   n- units are confined in the cavities of the 3D {Cu7Br6} n   n+ network to show low coordinated {CuN2} sites. Guanazolate ligands in 1 adopt an unprecedented pentadentate N1, N2, N4, diamino N-bridging mode (Scheme , type C) and some bromide ligands exhibit a very rare umbrella-like μ 4 bridging geometry. The first binary metal guanazolate 2 can be prepared exclusively either from Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in an alkaline hydrothermal environment, providing a facile synthetic condition. The 3D 3-connected topological net for 2 exhibits a seldom reported two-fold interpenetrated lvt-a net, which can be partially controlled through the fixing effect of inter-ligand hydrogen bonds. Cu(II) complex 3 comprises a rarely encountered 12-connected tetranuclear {Cu4(μ 3-OH)2} SBU, which is bridged by guanazolate ligands adopting a peculiar quadridentate coordination mode (Scheme , type B). This complex forms a new topology of 4-nodal net (43)(42.63.8)(42.84)(43.64.83), and that can be simplified to a non-interpenetrated pcu net, which is first constructed from multinuclear Cu(II) SBUs.

elements.content: Furthermore, physical properties of these complexes are also well investigated to establish useful function-structure correlations. Both 1 and 2 exhibit strong, broad and unstructured emissions and long luminescence lifetimes, which may be assigned to the 3[MLCT] ES. Particularly for 1, the 3[MC] or 3[MMLCT] ES should also be possible due to its shorter Cu···Cu distances than the sum of van der Waals radii for copper. Two different chromophores are incorporated into the coordination polymer matrix of 1, which provides a significant strategy to tune photoluminescent properties of complexes. All compounds of this study display a medium to high thermal stability, and 1 shows the highest one with its structure framework strikingly unchanged up to 540 °C, which is associated with its rigid and tight-connected structure, and especially with its stable 3D inorganic skeleton of {Cu7Br6} n . Compound 3 exhibits magnetic properties with four Cu(II) centers antiferromagnetically coupled in a tetranuclear array, which enables multiple and strong exchange interactions of J 1 = −95.1, J 2 = −152.7, J 3 = −55.4 cm−1 coming from μ-guanazolate, single or double μ 3-hydroxide superexchange pathways. Some significant magneto-structural correlations are discussed as well. On the basis of this work, further structure and property studies of the guanazole ligand with other metals are also under investigation in our laboratory.

On the basis of this work, further structure and property studies of the guanazole ligand with other metals are also under investigation in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of CuBr (0.14g, 1.00 mmol), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.05g, 0.25 mmol), and Hdatrz (0.05g, 0.5 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner; 2 mL of ethanol and 8 mL of water were then added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 5 min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 160 °C. The temperature was held for 3 days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 0.5 °C min−1 to form pale-yellow prism crystals of 1. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C4H8Br6Cu8N10: C, 4.06; H, 0.68; N, 11.83; Br, 40.49. Found: C, 4.04; H, 0.69; N, 11.86; Br, 40.45%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm−1) for complex 1: 3325 (s), 1682 (m), 1650 (s), 1632 (s), 1600 (m), 1563 (m), 1516 (m), 1477 (m), 1375 (m) 1097 (w), 764 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu(datrz)] (2)

The reaction was carried out in a procedure similar to that for 1, using CuCl2•2H2O (0.17g, 1.0 mmol) and aqueous ammonia (25%, 2.0 mL) instead of CuBr and 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid. Brown prism crystals of 2 were isolated in 87% yield. Anal. Calcd (%) for C2H4CuN5: C, 14.86; H, 2.49; N, 43.33. Found: C, 14.85; H, 2.51; N, 43.31%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm−1) for complex 2: 3335 (m), 3138 (s), 1623 (m), 1560 (m), 1482 (m), 1455 (m), 1400 (s), 1161 (w), 1095 (w), 1044 (w), 755 (w), 699 (w), 631 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>4</sub>(datrz)<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>] (3)

A mixture of CuSO4•5H2O (0.25g, 1.00 mmol), and Hdatrz (0.05g, 0.5 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner; 10 mL of water were then added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 10 min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 150 °C. The temperature was held for 4 days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 1.0 °C min−1 to form blue sheet crystals of 3. Yield: 90%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C4H10Cu4N10O10S2: C, 7.10; H, 1.49; N, 20.71; S, 9.48. Found: C, 7.08; H, 1.52; N, 20.70; S, 9.43%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm−1) for complex 3: 3430 (m), 3165 (m), 1622 (m), 1525 (w), 1401 (s), 1169 (w), 1104 (w), 1023 (w), 965 (w), 641 (w), 609 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu(datrz)] (2)

The reaction was carried out in a procedure similar to that for 1, using CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.17g, 1.0 mmol) and aqueous ammonia (25%, 2.0 mL) instead of CuBr and 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid. Brown prism crystals of 2 were isolated in 87% yield. Anal. Calcd (%) for C2H4CuN5: C, 14.86; H, 2.49; N, 43.33. Found: C, 14.85; H, 2.51; N, 43.31%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm-1) for complex 2: 3335 (m), 3138 (s), 1623 (m), 1560 (m), 1482 (m), 1455 (m), 1400 (s), 1161 (w), 1095 (w), 1044 (w), 755 (w), 699 (w), 631 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2] (3)

A mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.25g, 1.00 mmol), and Hdatrz (0.05g, 0.5 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner; 10 mL of water were then added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 10 min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 150 °C. The temperature was held for 4 days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 1.0 °C min-1 to form blue sheet crystals of 3. Yield: 90%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C4H10Cu4N10O10S2: C, 7.10; H, 1.49; N, 20.71; S, 9.48. Found: C, 7.08; H, 1.52; N, 20.70; S, 9.43%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm-1) for complex 3: 3430 (m), 3165 (m), 1622 (m), 1525 (w), 1401 (s), 1169 (w), 1104 (w), 1023 (w), 965 (w), 641 (w), 609 (w).

cln_elements.content:
The TG curve of 1 (Figure a) is almost unchanged up to 320 °C, which suggests that its framework is robust and thermally stable. Then a steady, moderate to steep weight loss up to 720 °C is observed without any obvious well-defined plateau, and that is associated with the decomposition of organic ligands and the sublimation of CuBr (exptl, 89.19%; calcd, 89.27%) to leave a residue of Cu. TGA-QMS analysis reveal that the loss of NH2 and CN groups dominates the initial decomposition phase (320 to 500 °C) of guanazole ligands, authenticated by detectable ion currents of NH2 + (m/z = 16) and CN+ (m/z = 26), as shown in Figure a and b. Above 540 °C, detectable ion currents (m/z = 16, NH2 +; m/z = 26, 52 for CN+; m/z = 38 for C2N+) are associated with the complete combustion of organic ligands, leading to the structure collapse. The thermodiffraction profile for 1 (Figure ) is strikingly unchanged between 50 and 540 °C, manifesting that its structural integrity can be retained far beyond the initial decomposition temperature and partial loss of organic components does not result in structure collapse. This observation of 1 is seldom reported in copper-triazolate (or substituted triazolate) complexes, and may be mainly attributed to its rigid and stable 3D inorganic network of {Cu7Br6} n which is densely linked by pentadentate guanazolate ligands as discussed before. It is noteworthy that complex 1 displays the highest thermal stability among all compounds of this study, and it is also much higher than other reported Cu−triazolate structures. The remarkably high thermal stability of 1 is related with its peculiar molecular structure, and that also suggests a straightforward way to tune structure-related thermal stabilities of metal-organic complexes.

The TG curves of 2 and 3 (Figures S3 and S4, ) are likewise unchanged up to 280 °C, showing a moderate high thermal stability of these materials. For 2, a weight loss from 280 to 450 °C is consistent with the decomposition of organic ligands (exptl, 50.12%; calcd, 50.79%). Differently, complex 3 manifests a very sharp loss of hydroxy groups and all organic components in the temperature range of 280-365 °C (exptl, 33.24%; calcd, 34.03%). After a plateau of stability between 365 and 625 °C, the second weight loss process is observed, corresponding to the combustion of sulfate groups (exptl, 18.41%; calcd, 18.94%).

Magnetic Properties of 3

Magnetic susceptibility data for polycrystalline sample of 3 are displayed in the form of a χ m T and χ m vs T plot, where χ m is the molar magnetic susceptibility as calculated with correcting for the diamagnetic contribution. The room-temperature value of χ m T for 3 is 0.54 cm3 K mol−1 (Figure ), which is significantly smaller than the expected value for four uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g = 2.0 (4χ m,Cu T = 1.5 cm3 K mol−1 and S = 1/2). Upon cooling, the χ m T value decreases continuously from room temperature until it vanishes near 2.5 K. The value of χ m is 0.0017 cm3 mol−1 at room temperature, and it increases smoothly to a maximum of 0.0046 cm3 mol−1 at 27 K and finally decreases to 0.0039 cm3 mol−1 at 2K.
